Literature Review: The genetics of kidney disease has undergone a significant transformation over the past few decades, with the identification of hundreds of genetic causes of chronic kidney disease (CKD). These discoveries have not only expanded our understanding of the molecular underpinnings of kidney diseases but have also highlighted the unexpected role of rare disorders in contributing to both adult and pediatric CKD. Traditional genetic approaches, which relied on the study of large families with multiple affected members, have been instrumental in identifying many of these genetic kidney diseases. However, the advent of massively parallel sequencing (MPS) and improvements in genotype imputation have revolutionized the field, enabling the analysis of rare variants in large cohorts of unrelated individuals. This has led to significant advancements in personalized care for patients and has opened new avenues for research into genetic kidney diseases. The contribution of rare disorders to the field of nephrology cannot be overstated. While individually rare, these disorders collectively represent a significant portion of CKD cases, underscoring the importance of genetic testing in the diagnosis and management of kidney diseases. The use of MPS has been particularly transformative, allowing for the rapid and cost-effective sequencing of entire genomes or exomes. This technology has facilitated the identification of novel gene-disease associations, many of which involve rare variants that would have been difficult to detect using traditional methods. Moreover, the integration of genomic data with clinical information has enabled the development of precision medicine approaches in nephrology, tailoring treatment strategies to the genetic makeup of individual patients. Collapsing analysis, a statistical method used to identify rare variants associated with disease by aggregating them across genes or genomic regions, has emerged as a powerful tool in the study of genetic kidney diseases. This approach has been particularly useful in identifying genes involved in rare kidney disorders, providing insights into the biological pathways underlying these conditions. Furthermore, the application of collapsing analysis in large cohorts has revealed the polygenic nature of many kidney diseases, highlighting the complex interplay between rare and common genetic variants in disease susceptibility. The advancements in genomics and the identification of rare genetic disorders have also had a profound impact on patient care. Genetic testing has become an integral part of the diagnostic workup for patients with CKD, enabling the identification of specific genetic causes of disease in a significant proportion of cases. This has important implications for patient management, including the selection of appropriate therapies, the assessment of disease progression, and the provision of genetic counseling to patients and their families. In conclusion, the study of rare genetic disorders has significantly advanced our understanding of the genetics of kidney disease. The integration of MPS, collapsing analysis, and precision medicine approaches has transformed the field, leading to the identification of novel gene-disease associations and the development of personalized treatment strategies for patients with CKD. As our knowledge of the genetic basis of kidney diseases continues to grow, it is likely that rare disorders will play an increasingly important role in shaping the future of nephrology.
